FacilityName: Stewart Creek West Wastewater Treatment Plant

_prev_prog_2.Description: Chlorine is stored at the Stewart Creek WWTP in three ton cylinders. Chlorine detectors are located at the storage area and in the chlorine feed building in case of a leak. If a leak is detected an autodialer calls the NTMWD Control Room in Wylie which is manned twenty four hours per day, seven days per week. If an alarm is received an awareness level operator is dispatched to the site to evaluate the alarm. If it is determined a release has occured the NTMWD emergency response team and the City of Frisco Fire Department will be notified.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
FACILITY DESCRIPTION
The North Texas Municipal Water District is a regional entity that treats water, wastewater, and solid waste for four counties in the north Texas area. The Stewart Creek West Wastewater Treatment is located in Frisco, at 5100 4th Army Memorial Drive. The facility is owned and operated by the North Texas Municipal Water District (NTMWD).

COMPLIANCE
NTMWD maintains compliance with the U.S. Environmental Protection AgencyA?s (USEPA) regulations for the prevention and mitigation of accidental releases of extremely hazardous substances under section 112(r) of the Clean Air Act.   Facilities covered by the regulations (40 CFR 68) are required to implement a risk management program and submit a description of the program (called a risk management plan, or RMP) to USEPA.  

The Stewart Creek Wastewater Treatment Plant (WWTP) falls under this regulation because of the onsite storage and use of chlorine.  The amount stored exceeds the threshold limits specified by the USEPA, thereby making the facility subject to compliance with the regulation.  

The following information summarizes the Stewart Creek WWTP 2009 update:

REGULATED SUBSTANCES
The Stewart Creek WWTP uses chlorine as a disinfectant in the wastewater treatment process.   
1. Chlorine
The Stewart Creek WWTP regularly has a maximum storage quantity of 4 tons of chlorine at its facility.  The chlorine is stored in 4 one-ton cylinders.  The total amount of chlorine exceeds the threshold limit of 2,500 pounds set by the USEPA.  Chlorine is delivered to the Stewart Creek WWTP by truck.    

A release of chlorine gas could potentially occur at the chlorine storage area or at the chlorine process areas.

HAZARD ASSESSMENT
Malcolm Pirnie, Inc. reviewed and updated the offsite consequence analyses at Stewart Creek WWTP by identifying and documenting a worse case scenario and one alternate release scenario for chlorine.   EPAA?s RMP*Comp was used as the model for the resubmission.  

The results of this

review are documented and are maintained as part of the RMP records.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
The accident history for the Stewart Creek WWTP was reviewed for the period from June 2004 through June 2009.  During this period of time, no accidental releases of chlorine occurred that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on-site, or off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage or any environmental impact.

PREVENTION PROGRAM
The NTMWD maintains a consistent accidental release prevention program to eliminate or minimize releases of chlorine at Stewart Creek WWTP.  The program consists of seven elements:

1. Safety Information
NTMWD has maintained information concerning process chemicals, technology, and equipment as part of their risk management program at Stewart Creek WWTP.  The information is made available to employees and contractors at Stewart Creek WWTP who will work in the chlorine process area.  Emergency response planners can also use the information to develop training programs and procedures.

2. Hazard Review
A hazard review of chlorine processes and procedures is conducted at least every five (5) years to evaluate potential causes and consequences of accidental releases.  A chlorine process hazard analysis using the A?What-IfA? method was conducted by Malcolm Pirnie, Inc. with the assistance of Stewart Creek WWTP plant management and staff familiar with the processA? operation and maintenance in May, 2009.  Existing precautions were reviewed and determined to be adequate.  Potential changes in operating, maintenance, and other process safety management procedures that could further improve the overall safety of the chlorine system was identified.

The results of this review are documented and are maintained as part of the RMP records.  

3. Operating procedures
NTMWD have developed and implemented written operating procedures that provide instructions and step for conducting activities associated w

ith the chlorine processes at Stewart Creek WWTP consistent with the safety information. Stewart Creek WWTP operating procedures include startup, shutdown, and emergency operating procedures, and describe how the system should be operated in order to minimize the chances of an accidental release. The procedures also emphasize safety considerations during operation and address hazardous situations that can occur and how to correct them.

4. Training
All Stewart Creek WWTP staff currently involved in chlorine processes have been trained in the classroom and/or during on-the-job training in an overview of the processes and in the operating procedures, as is new staff assigned to the processes.  Training includes emphasis on safety and health, hazards, emergency operations including shutdown, and safe work practices.  Refresher training is provided at least every three years to ensure Stewart Creek WWTP staff understands and adheres to current operating procedures.  

5. Maintenance
Stewart Creek WWTP has developed and implemented a preventive and corrective maintenance program to ensure equipment used to process, store, or handle chlorine is functioning properly and installed to minimize the risk of releases.   The program addresses equipment testing, inspection, and preventive maintenance schedules, and documentation of equipment testing, inspection, and preventive and corrective maintenance activities. 

6. Compliance audits
USEPAA?s risk management rule requires that Stewart Creek WWTP complete a compliance audit for its risk management program at least once every 3 years. The primary goals of conducting a compliance audit are to verify compliance with risk management rule requirements and good process safety practices, identify process safety or program deficiencies and develop corrective actions, and increase safety awareness among Stewart Creek WWTP staff. 

Malcolm Pirnie, Inc., with the assistance of Stewart Creek WWTP plant management and staff familiar with t

he processes operation and maintenance, conducted an audit in February 2009. The results of this both audits, in addition to recommendations made, are documented and are maintained as part of the RMP records. 

7. Incident Investigation
Stewart Creek WWTP management investigates each incident that resulted in or could reasonably have resulted in a catastrophic release of chlorine. A process to identify the underlying causes of incidents and implement procedures for preventing similar events has been developed. 

An incident investigation team will be established following criteria established in the Stewart Creek WWTP risk management program.  As part of the investigation, an incident report will be prepared to recommend system changes (i.e., operational modifications, additional training and competency requirements), to prevent a similar incident from occurring in the future. The incident investigation report and any changes resulting from the report will be reviewed with all staff members who operate and maintain the applicable system.

No incidents were reported between 2004 and 2009

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN
An Emergency Response Plan (ERP) has been developed for Stewart Creek WWTP, which provides specific emergency response procedures for accidental releases of chlorine to ensure that emergency response coverage is available 24 hours per day, 7 days per week.  These procedures include leak investigation, operational-level response activities, and communications to coordinate response activities with outside agencies, such as the local fire department and a environmental response contractor, in the event of an emergency. 

NTMWD will be updating the ERP into an NIMS-compliant all-hazard integrated contingency plan (ICP) in 2009.  The ICP format minimizes duplication in the preparation and use of emergency response and risk management plans for various regulatory requirements, and will eliminate confusion for Stewart Creek WWTP staff that would have had to decide

which plan applies to a particular emergency.

RECOMMENDED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
A? Considering upgrading the current chlorine areas to include enclosure and scrubber.  
A? Considering interlocking the leak detectors to turn off the system
